docs.lead_paragraph: On June 14, 2001, doctors at a hospital in Greenville, N.C., undertook what for transplant experts was a routine operation, removing a healthy kidney from one person and placing it another. The procedure, performed nearly 5,300 times last year in the United States, is widely considered the safest transplant operation. Complications in kidney transplants are considered extremely rare, with only 3 of 10,000 donors dying. Recipients, aided by powerful anti-rejection drugs, enjoy lives free from waiting lists and dialysis machines. Donors, frequently family members, express awe at the knowledge that their gifts mean so much.

headline.main: For Family, Selfless Act Goes Awry

docs.abstract: Carole Tarrant Cases column on kidney transplant operation that revived her ailing mentally retarded brother but left her 69-year-old mother, whose kidney was used for transplant, paralyzed and brain damaged from stroke suffered day after surgery and living in nursing home (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a third of seriously ill patients who requested that doctors ease their discomfort instead of prolonging their lives appear to have had their wishes overlooked, a new study reports. The findings were based on a study of 1,185 Medicare patients at five teaching hospitals across the country who were suffering illnesses like multiple organ failure, cancer and congestive heart failure.
docs.abstract: Study of 1,185 Medicare patients, published in current Journal of American Geriatrics Society, finds more than one third of seriously ill patients who requested that doctors ease their discomfort rather than prolong their lives appear to have their wishes ignored; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins have been shown to provide significant help for people at high risk for heart attack and stroke. But a new study offers a note of caution. Patients who are taking the drugs should continue doing so if they are hospitalized for chest pain. If they stop taking the statins, they may face almost triple the risk of death or nonfatal heart attack as those who continue to take them, according to a report in the current issue of Circulation, an American Heart Association journal.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Germany's Kerckhoff Heart Center, in report published in current issue of Circulation, find that cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins provide significant help for those at high risk for heart attack and stroke; caution that patients hospitalized for chest pain face almost triple the risk of death or nonfatal heart attack if they stop taking statins (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite promise shown in the lab that the spermicide nonoxynol-9 may help prevent diseases like gonorrhea and chlamydia, the product appears to offer no benefit to women against sexually transmitted diseases, a new study shows. The researchers, writing in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, said the infection rate was about the same among people who used condoms plus the spermicide and those who used condoms alone.

headline.main: A Success in the Lab Fails in the Body

docs.abstract: University of Washington study, published in current issue of Journal of American Medical Assn, finds that spermicide nonoxynol-9 offers no benefit to women against sexually transmitted diseases (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One night last spring when I was on call at my hospital, I was paged at midnight. An alcoholic was spinning out of control in a ward. Could I admit him to the intensive care unit for observation? Alcohol withdrawal is usually uncomplicated, and patients can be treated on a medical floor with sedation and close observation. But occasionally, patients can go very rapidly into full-blown delirium tremens, with seizures, confusion and visual and tactile hallucinations that make them feel as if spiders are crawling all over the skin.

headline.main: Learning to Cope When Hospital Patients Turn Violent

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar article, recalling his own encounter with violent patient who was undergoing alcohol withdrawal, on doctors, nurses and other health care workers who are assaulted, sometimes fatally, by violent patients; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a suburban strip mall midway between downtown Denver and health-conscious Boulder, there is a place where people can go and order blood tests to detect any number of medical problems, like high cholesterol, diabetes, H.I.V. and prostate and ovarian cancer. It is neither a doctor's office nor a traditional laboratory that requires a physician's referral for medical tests. It is a retail store, where all that people need is cash, a check or a credit card to find out what ails them.

headline.main: Blood-Test Labs Bypass Doctors, Spurring Debate

docs.abstract: Article on growing number of laboratories that are opening up across US and on Internet that offer tests directly to consumers without doctor referrals; in addition, estimated 10 to 15 percent of existing commercial and hospital labs offer tests to consumers; many doctors question medical implications of patients trying to diagnose conditions and interpret test results themselves; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnancy and childbirth are rife with hazards. Those factors under personal control -- like weight issues and poor nutrition, overwork or lack of fitness -- should not become additional burdens. Unfortunately, for many millions of women of childbearing age, one or more of these problems compromise their chances of having a healthy, full-term pregnancy and increase the health risks to both mothers and their babies.

headline.main: Taking Care of Baby, Before the Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column offers advice to women on controlling weight and eating healthy diet before becoming pregnant; notes overweight women who become pregnant face much greater chance of complications both for themselves and fetus; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A decision to equip 356 state employees with workstations designed to reduce repetitive stress injuries led to a 40 percent reduction in computer-related health complaints in less than a year, a study found. Workers in the Office of Information Technology in New Jersey reported substantially fewer problems with their backs, elbows, arms, hands, necks and eyes, according to a study in the current Proceedings of the Human Factors and Ergonomics Society.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by Dr Alan Hedge of Cornell University and Mary Rudakewych and Lisa Valent-Weitz of New Jersey Health and Safety Office, published in current issue of Proceedings of the Human Factors and Ergonomics Society, finds that NJ state employees working at ergonomically designed workstations had 40 percent reduction in repetitive stress computer-related health complaints over one year period; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some children who exhibit attention and hyperactivity problems may really be suffering from a sleep disorder, researchers suggest. A study found a significant link between problems like snoring at night and behavioral problems during the day. If the findings are confirmed, said the lead author, Dr. Ronald Chervin of the Michael S. Aldrich Sleep Disorders Laboratory at the University of Michigan, it may mean that simple fatigue causes the problem.

headline.main: Night Problems May Spill Over Into Day

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Michigan sleep disorders laboratory publish study in current issue of Pediatrics suggesting that some children exhibiting attention and hyperactivity problems may really have snoring problem; drawing (M)
